Maintain silence while devotees are praying, and be mindful of your actions while exploring the temple grounds. If you want to avoid crowds, consider going on a weekday or earlier in the day. Be aware that some ceremonies might limit access to certain areas. Overall, Kelaniya Temple seems to be a popular destination for both pilgrims and tourists, offering a beautiful space for cultural immersion and spiritual reflection.

Kelaniya Rajamaha viharaya is one of the most sacred ancient Buddhist temple located in Kelaniya, Gampaha District, Sri Lanka. It is among the country's sixteen holiest Buddhist shrines (Solosmasthana) (Which is one of the 16 places where lord Budhda has visited) The Kelaniya Stupa enshrined a gem-studded throne on which the Buddha sat and preached. Lord Budhdha's second visit to Nagadeepaya, Sri Lanka was in the fifth year of enlightenment to settle a dispute between two Naga Kings, Chulodara and Mahodara over the possession of a Gem Studded throne. After having listened to the Dhamma sermons by Buddha the Naga kings paid homage to Buddha with overwhelming faith and the throne was offered to Lord Buddha by two Naga kings. The throne was then presented to Naga King Maniakkika- Ruler of Kelaniya by Lord Budhdha as he pleaded for a souvenir to worship. King Maniakkika in turn constructed a Cetiya (Stupa) covering the Gem studded Throne in Kelaniya for thousands of devotees to worship and invited lord Budhdha to visit the holy site. Lord Buddha together with 500 Arahats (Supremely enlightened beings) visited Kelaniya and preached Dhamma, on Wesak Poya Day, after eighth year of enlightenment as Lord Budhdha .It was lord Buddha's third and final visit to Sri Lanka. ‚ÄúThe sin of a life time are all rendered null, Once Kelaniya is worshiped a single time"

Also known as Kelaniya Temple is a Buddhist temple, with a history believed to be dated back to before 500 BC, located in Kelaniya, Sri Lanka, a few miles from Colombo. It is believed by the devotees that the temple was constructed during the third and final visit of the Lord Buddha to Sri Lanka which occurred eight years after Lord Budda was said to have gained enlightenment. Mahawansa records specify that the original Stupa, situated beside the main temple,  enshrined a gem-studded throne on which the Buddha sat and preached.  The temple is well-known for its reclining Buddha and the paintings, very detailed in brilliant colors, which adore the interior walls of the temple which depict events in the life of the Buddha in Sri Lanka and events that took place in the Jataka tales.  Although it can be crowded mid-day you gain more knowledge of the temple grounds because of all of the activities that take place during the day.  There are a group of monks that live on the temple grounds who will be observed monitoring the activities and offering blessings to the devotees that are on the ground to pray and pay respects.  Plan on spending about one hour on the grounds in order to view all of the important activities and structures.  You will be required to remove your shoes to walk around the grounds.  If your feet are tender at least wear socks for your walk around the stone or sand filled payment.  Stairs are minimal.

The Kelaniya Raja Maha Vihara simply known as   Kelaniya Temple, built on the banks of the Kelani River.  Temple is a Buddhist worship temple close to  Colombo. It is a culturally glorious processions, with dressed and LED lighted Elephants, cultural dancers and many more. it is a sacred temple because Buddhist believes eight years after gaining enlightenment the Lord Buddha visited temple premises (before 500 BC), 500 arahants (spiritual practitioners who have attained a high state of enlightenment) as third and final visit to Sri Lanka on invitation of  King Maniakkhitha to a meal. However, Sri Lankan became Buddhist after centuries, with the arrival of monk known as Mihinda in third century BC. The land was subsequently consecrated, and the King built a temple and chaithya. Inside the chaithya were buried several relics, including hair, the utensils the Buddha had used for the meal and the gem-studded chair on which he sat and preached, as believed. However it is believed, Uttiya brother of the first Buddhist king Devanampiyatissa, renovated (after two centuries)  the temple for the first time, and built quarters for the monks. The present temple rebuild in 1767 during the Dutch period of Sri Lanka, because it was believed, former construction was destroyed during Portuguese ruling. There are pre- Buddhist era legends linked with this premises such as Hindu epic, the Ramayana. King Vibeeshana, King Ravana‚Äôs successor, had his palace on the banks of the River. Some of the murals outside the temple depict Vibeeshana‚Äôs coronation however no adequate historical evidence for the same.

Egoda and Megoda Kaleniya..by Hasangani Edema Seven miles away from Colombo, the Kelaniya Raja Maha Viharaya is one of the most sought after Buddhist temples. It is believed to have been graced by Lord Buddha himself, on the eighth year after his enlightenment on a wesak Poya day together with 500 Arahats. The purpose of this visit was believed to have been according to the records of mahavamsa, was to reconcile an argument between two ‚ÄòNaga‚Äô Kings, Chulodara and Mahodara over a gem studded throne at Nagadeepa. This was also believed to have been Lord Buddha‚Äôs third visit on the invitation made by King Maniakkikha. As the tale goes on, King Maniakkikha build a stupa enshrining the gem-studded throne on which Lord Buddha preached, and also included a handful of hair gifted by Lord Buddha himself. Kelaniya temple is believed to have been built prior to the 5th century B.C. and is not clear as to who exactly built the original stupa except the folklore of King Maniakkika. Prince Uttiya, who was believed to be the brother of King Devanampiyatissa, made renovations to the viharaya. However with the Dravidian invaders from South India, destroyed the original constructions, but was reconstructed. Portuguese in 1510 destroyed the medieval temple, where beautiful sculpture and murals dating back to the anuradhpura era was lost forever. The temple was however rebuilt again during the Dutch empire under the patronage of King Kirthi Sri Rajasinghe. It was later renovated in the 20th century under the guidance of Helena Wijewardana, where the deteriorated paintings were restored to almost its original state by Solius Mendis. We started our journey by visiting the Kaleniya temple which is situated on the other side of the Kelani River. This is thought to have been the actual temple premises, which most have now forgotten. According to folklore and the inscriptions in the temple vicinity, the temple was built to commemorate Lord Buddha‚Äôs visit and it is believed to have been the place where he enjoyed the refreshing water of the Kelani River. The temple vicinity is not as big as the Kelaniya Raja Maha Viharaya but holds the essentials of a Buddhist temple. The ‚ÄòEgoda‚Äô Kelaniya temple is situated very close to the Kaleni River unlike the Kelaniya Raja Maha Viharaya. We walked towards the banks of the river in search of the ‚ÄòThotiya‚Äô and his ‚ÄòParuwa‚Äô to get across as you would have long years ago. For a mere amount of Rs 10/= (both ways), he took us over to the other side, where we were walked to the bigger and prestigious temple. If you are a resident of Sri Lanka, despite your ethnicity, you would have visited the Kelaniya Rajamaha Viharaya at some point of your life. It is always filled with the hustle and bustle of devotees, therefore avoid visiting the temple on a poya days and other special Buddhist holidays. Even on other days, it would be ideal to visit the temple early in the morning in order to avoid the crowd so that you would get the chance to simply embrace the temple itself and get lost in its beautiful murals. The dagoba of the Kelaniya Rajamaha Viharaya is unlike others as it is shaped in the manner of a rice grain heap, which is called ‚ÄòDhanyakara‚Äô. The stupa itself has several names to itself ‚ÄòKalyani Chaithyaya‚Äô and ‚ÄòKelani Seya‚Äô. The ‚ÄòAluth Vihara Ge‚Äô stands on a stone plinth, with a roof built in the Kandyan architectural style including a design of an octagon.  It consists of four image houses. ‚ÄòOth Pilimage‚Äô is the oldest section, consisting of a large reclining Buddha statue and two seated Buddha statues. ‚ÄòRaja Pilimage‚Äô consists of older murals from the Kandyan era. ‚ÄòRan Pilimage‚Äô consists of murals which are modern (18th-20th century), depicting important occasions of Buddhism in Sri Lanka. Personally, for me the best mural paintings lie here in the Ran Pilimage, where it is unlike any other I have seen. A painting can depict a thousand words, thus telling us stories of Prince Danta and Princess Hemamala‚Äôs journey with the sacred tooth relic to King Vijaya‚Äôs arrival. The temple is believed to have links to the Hindu epic, the ‚ÄòRamayana‚Äô. The sculptures surrounding the ‚ÄòAluth Vihara Ge‚Äô clearly King Vibeeshana‚Äôs coronation and other Hindu gods and goddesses. The Kelaniya temple also hosts the Duruthu Perehera, held in annually in January. Amidst the chanting of devotees, we made our way back to the edge of the Kelani River to our journey back to the other side on the ‚ÄòParuwa‚Äô. There we saw a ritual we normally would not have seen in any other temple. Two older well-dressed ladies asked the ‚ÄòThotiya‚Äô to take them to the middle of the river. Which one was negotiating the terms the other prepared an offering with small stupa and flowers. Both got on to the ‚ÄòParuwa‚Äô and when they reached the middle, set a float their offering while chanting ‚Äògatha‚Äô. Something which you don‚Äôt get to see every day. Despite being destroyed several times, the Kelani temple is a special place of worship for Buddhist devotees and also a place of great historic and cultural value to us Sri Lankans. Make sure to pay a visit if you ever get a chance to both Egoda and Megoda Kelaniya.

If a traveller who is asking for a place with ancient glory with local taste and traditional touch, your answer should be Kelaniya temple- Kelaniya Royal Monastery.  It  is only few kilometers off from Colombo metropolitan, easily accessible by using Colombo - Kandy main road. This serene plot of environment is situated by the beautiful Kelani River, one of Sri Lanka's the four great rivers. The history of Kelaniya extends to the era of the great king Ravana. His brother Vibhishana ruled Kelaniya as a provincical kingdom. Nowadays, Vibhishsna is worshiped in Kelaniya as the deity of the area. According to the chronicles of Sri Lanka it is said that Kelaniya was governed by Naga(cobra) tribe. At the time of Lord Buddha's arrival to Kelaniya, Naga King Maniakkitha was the ruler of Kelaniya. Lord Budda made his visit to Kelaniya as an invitation made by King Maniakkitha. Lord Buddha, accompanied 500 bikkus and pearched damma to royal gathering, for that he used a precious gem studded throne seat. Later, kelaniya stupa was built  enshrining the throne probably around 5th century BC, then which become the symbol of Kelaniya. According to great chronicle of Lanka -the Mahavamsa this stupa had been renovated by king Uttiya in 3rd century BC and later by king Yatalathissa. The golden era of Kelaniya Monastery was considered as kingdom of Kotte, during that period its infrastructure was greatly extended under the guidance of the great king Parakramabahu VI. With the time Portuguese destroyed the temple to ground. During Dutch reign condition become better and Kandyan King Kirthi Sri Rajasingha renovated the temple and existing up to now. There are four entrances to upper sacred terrace which contains the stupa, image shrine, Bodhi tree, bell tower and few other buildings. The stupa is architecturally important and its dome has the shape of rice grain head hence called as Dhanyakara stupa. This stupa in its pure white coloration make the environment calm and peaceful. The image house contains 4 sections including both old and new additions. These 4 sections are Raja pilima ge- king's image house, oth pilima ge - recline Buddha image house, aluth vihara ge- new temple house and ran pilima ge- golden Buddha image house. Oth pilima ge was the oldest part of the entire temple. This image shrine is well known due to its unique paintings. Raja pilima ge and oth pilinage contain painting belongs to Kandyan era. Other sections contains paintings done by Solius Mendis. All the facilities including food, parking available close by. One can enjoy breeze from Kelani river by a boat ride.

The Chief Incumbent (Chief Priest) is Venerable Professor Kollupitiye Mahinda Sangharakkhitha Thera. Kelaniya temple  which is in Kelniya village, situated on the banks of Kelani river, which is originating from Sri Pada in Maskeliya . Due to the fact, it makes this temple‚Äôs surroundings attractive, calm, serine and mind concentration place for the devotees who come to worship this holy land. Kelaniya Temple can be reached by A1 main motor road running from Colombo to Kandy and turning left at Paliagoda and by Railway getting down at Kelaniya from Polgahawela/ Gampaha destination train. But make sure from the announcement that Kelaniya is mentioned as a stopping station. From Kelaniya station, take a  tuk tuk to the Kelniya temple. You can come straight from south highway, taking exit at Kadawatha. Kelaniya temple both shows historic and cultural values. An 18-foot stone statue of the Bodhisattva Avalokitesvara has been erected at the temple. Buddhists believe that the Lord Buddha visited to Sri Lanka, eight years after gaining enlightenment during his third and final visit before 500 BC.There was a gem-studded throne on the original Stupa at Kelaniya Temple where the Lord Buddha sat and preached. There is a large stone displayed where Lord Buddha kept his rouge (clothe he was wearing) for bathing in the Kelani river. Kelani temple is one of 3 sacred places where the Lord Buddha has arrived in Sri Lanka other being Mahiyanna and Badulla, Muthiyanngana Temple. Much of its land was confiscated during the Portuguese empire although the temple flourished during the Kotte era. However, there were new gifts of land under the Dutch empire and under the patronage of King Kirthi Sri Rajasingha and the temple was rebuilt then. In 1510 AD , the temple was destroyed by the Portuguese, who had then conquered the Maritime provinces of the country. The original Temple and the Stupa or the Dageba, was built in 5th Century BC, but none of the earlier structure survive today. It also states that the temple was rebuilt by King Vijayabahu III, (1232-1236) and King Parakrama Bahu II (1236-1270).        The Kelaniya Temple was five stories high with traditional styling and roofing as mentioned in the Sri Lankan chronicle "Chulavansa". Paintings found here was done by a native artist, Solias Mendis. The temple is also famous for its image of the reclining Gautama Buddha and painting. The paintings shown here depict important events in the life of the Buddha, in the history of Buddhism in Sri Lanka, also incidents from the Jataka tales. The temple is entrenched with wood carvings, stone carvings drawings, paintings and statues etc. The Duruthu Maha Perehera procession is in each January and Esala Maha Perahera (procession) in August are conducted by the Kelaniya Temple annually. Perahara festival is the most beautiful time period for someone to visit here. You will be able to see the beauty of a cultural festival with Sri Lankan traditions and cultural dances, music, and see many elephants dressed in beautiful cloths etc. Locals come here to worship and foreigners gather here to see the arts, paintings, carvings and it's beauty. This Temple Kelaniya Rajamaha viharaya is near to colombo Buddhism /Ààbud…™z…ôm/[1][2] is a religion[note 1][3] and dharma that encompasses a variety of traditions, beliefs and spiritual practices largely based on teachings attributed to the Buddha. Buddhism originated in India, from where it spread through much of Asia, whereafter it declined in India during the middle ages. Two major extant branches of Buddhism are generally recognized by scholars: Theravada (Pali: "The School of the Elders") and Mahayana (Sanskrit: "The Great Vehicle"). Buddhist schools vary on the exact nature of the path to liberation, the importance and canonicity of various teachings and scriptures, and especially their respective practices.[4][5] Practices of Buddhism include Refuge, Samatha, VipassanƒÅ, the Mahayana practice of Bodhicitta and the Vajrayana practices of Generation stage and Completion stage. In Theravada the ultimate goal is the attainment of the sublime state of nirvana, achieved by practicing the Noble Eightfold Path (also known as the Middle Way), thus escaping what is seen as a cycle of suffering and rebirth.[6] Theravada has a widespread following in Sri Lanka and Southeast Asia. Mahayana, which includes the traditions of Pure Land, Zen, Nichiren Buddhism, Shingon and Tiantai (Tendai), is found throughout East Asia. Rather than Nirvana, Mahayana instead aspires to Buddhahood via the bodhisattva path,[8] a state wherein one remains in the cycle of rebirth to help other beings reach awakening. Vajrayana, a body of teachings attributed to Indian siddhas, may be viewed as a third branch or merely a part of Mahayana. Tibetan Buddhism, which preserves the Vajrayana teachings of eighth century India,[9] is practiced in regions surrounding the Himalayas, Mongolia[10] and Kalmykia.[11] Tibetan Buddhism aspires to Buddhahood or rainbow body.[12] Buddhists number between an estimated 488 million[web 1] and 535 million,[13] making it one of the world's major religions

A younger brother of Ravana, Vibhisana, like his brother, propitiated Brahma, and obtained a boon in return of a vow. The vow was that he would never commit an unworthy action even in the greatest extremity.
